comments.commentBody: Internal memos from the White House and its consultants (those trying to make this a success) that have been made public in the last two weeks have made clear its disastrous roll-out was predicted monthl beforehand because of the way the program was being put together.  Clearly, the cause has not been yet another  mythical "vast right wing conspiracy" to ruin the website.  Just fix it, and stop making up imaginary villains upon which to deflect the blame.

You know what else are the roads crammed full of? Cabs. And trucks. And cars.

I'm glad you are the cab driver who uses turn signals while changing lanes.

People use the service because they do not have to walk, peddle or drive.  That is the purpose of the service.  Plus, you better look inward to all the mass of cabs causing pollution, merging without signaling and driving like maniacs.  Why should anyone use your service??

I don't understand why anyone would use this service.  Our roads are already crammed full of bikes!  These 'bikers' drive like maniacs.  Although I haven't seen any of these delivery people do anything illegal.. yet.  I will call the police immediately if I *DO* happen to see one so much as merge without giving the proper hand signal.  My job as a Manhattan (not to mention North Jersey and Long Island if it's an airport run) cab driver is dangerous enough without people riding around like maniacs and potentially putting myself *AND* my passengers at risk.

So, you have your health care card now?

Because "signing up" isn't enough. You have to send in your payment, and the insurer needs to receive it. Since Covered California uses the Federal payment system, and the Federal payment system hasn't been built yet, you're still out of luck. Let's hope they solve it before you need health care. Showing your signup to a doctor just won't cut it.
Well what else can you say then, I guess utopia is upon us!

@Crooktooth, I have received my "welcome" letter for the new Kaiser Permanente plan (I'm already a Kaiser member in 2013), so yes, they know I'm enrolled. Since the plan begins Jan. 1, the payment will not be billed for another week or two, but obviously Kaiser has me in the system.

Yes, it's working just fine out here. Another thing I just saw on TV (and have been seeing a lot) is a really well-produced set of commercials for Covered California - it's a good ad campaign that's educating everyone about it.

Yes, it's working well, I signed up in early October. People need to relax about the Federal website - it's getting the kinks worked out, I've helped a friend in TX use it. Just be a little patient. The prices are good, and the side-by-side comparisons are clear.

We have a great Governor in CA. That helps, a lot. The feds had the sequester - which meant funding for everything (including website-building) got whacked with 10 percent cuts. Not surprised it had problems, but they're getting fixed.

crime stats are not accurate.  PC rewards precinct commanders with promotions if reported crimes appear lower.  NYPD posts an outside audit on crime reporting on their website.  It points out that the lower stats make the PC look good.  It also points out there is little discipline to commanders who erroniously reduce crime (no demotions or criminal charges).  Why would there be?  Integrity? I think not.  Even after that report, many man hours spent investigating stats, but no noticable discipline.  Time for a change.  Time for integrity.

It's time to put this tired argument to rest until a carrot cries out in pain like the animals slaughtered for our consumption.
Plants have no nervous system, and it doesn't take much more than basic reasoning or elementary biology to grasp that fact.
We have no reason to "thank" the carrot , nor the chicken, fish nor any other horrifically slaughtered animal.
I'm thankful for that very wise child, who learned far earlier than I did, that compassion for all living beings with whom we share this planet is a moral imperative.

This is very important, because we have to break the logjam in the ME and show that diplomacy and sacrifices will work instead of stalemate and war. Hope the final agreement wiorks. That will show the world that every problem has a way out of it....
There is no similarity between North Korea and Iran.  None, zero, zilch.

Perhaps Pato and Connie might spare a moment to consider that Netanyahu, and his nation, live constantly under an existential threat; and that his reactions might be tempered by the realization that this threat has just been substantially increased.  Concentrates his mind more fully, I imagine, than empty words -- accompanied by a short, equally empty document -- from Washington.

Israel is insisting on keeping Nuclear arsenal.Therefore,Israel & israelis are the last ones to provide ethical judgement.In addition, Israel over its history has used its military might to invade and bomb its neighbours ,while Iran was just issuing threatening words.There is a big difference between doing ,killing etc and threatening  by words without deed

Are you saying tat we should  ot even try and talk with Iran?  Kerry stated that, "we are not stupid nor are blind". There are other solutions rather than just bombing the country. We are also a sovereign nation and make our own foreign policy without interference  by other foreign countries.

The article itself says that reaching a final agreement is next to impossible. And what happens when there are a series of only interim agreements? And what makes anybody think that sanctions can be re-instated with the wave of a magic wand?
The fact is that the Middle East is against it (except of course for Syria bankrolled by Iran) because it still leaves Iran as the major negative player in the region and nobody cares about that.
The New Yorker in September reported that Iran bankrolled Assad to the tune of 7 billion dollars, just about the sum that Iran will make back.
I guess that means that the loosening of sanctions bankrolls Assad.
Good deal- for Iran and Assad.
but what about slavery? Or did you skip over that part?

I too remember reading GWTW over and over when I was in adolescence -- partly for the romance between Scarlett and Rhett, but also to delve into Scarlett's character. I admired her ability to be both charming and gritty, a dreamer (about Ashley) and yet the ultimate pragmatist (about everything else). I was searching for a role model during this formative time. Although even my young self realized that she was flawed, she persevered, and indeed, thrived, when her society fell apart while most everyone else tried to cling to dead social customs. The crisis generated by the Civil War and the Reconstruction freed her from the stultifying roles that women were expected to play in the Old South and allowed her to fully take advantage of her "head for figures" and to excel at running a business and to become prosperous. Yet, she felt the sting of judgment from other women, and worried that her mother would not approve of her actions. Melanie's character is the perfect foil to Scarlett's -- they highlight each other's strengths and weaknesses.

The movie has made it impossible for me to imagine Scarlett other than as Vivian Leigh phenomenally portrayed her. Equally mesmerizing, in a much quieter way, was Olivia DeHavilland's steady performance as Melanie. Interestingly, I think that there was zero chemistry between Clark Gable and Leigh and that his performance paled in comparison to the women's (and that includes the wonderful actress who played Mamie).

Yes...insightful...I am sure I would want a partner which revels in burning American flags after every Friday prayers and celebrates such Iranian "victories" as the suicide bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut. I am sure we all would want to cozy up to an Iranian partner which hangs homosexuals as criminals and sets new standards for misogyny.

And you got 8 thumbs up too....amazing.

"...without raising doubts about the Iranian intentions and goals."

Right now, everyone doubts Iran's intentions and goals as a result of Iran's continuing threats to destroy Israel. There needs to be solid and consistent evidence that the destruction of Israel is no longer a goal of the Iranians before this agreement can advance further.

This is the biggest challenge that a long-term deal faces. Hence, the doubts.

Isn't there a positive shift towards Israel and its legitimate right to exist of late on the part of Iran, duly articulated by Hassan Rouhani? Why can't this goodwill gesture be built further to improve a climate of trust?

> Prof. Dharma

"Isn't there a positive shift towards Israel and it's legitimate right to exist on the part of Iran"

The best I have seen is that Iran now agrees that the Holocaust took place. I guess that is a positive shift but not one that is going to eliminate doubts about Iran's intentions.

While an interim deal was expected to lay foundation for a final resolution of the Iranian nuclear issue for being the first confidence restoring measure between the US/West and Iran, it's rather turning out to be a new weapon of harassment and humiliation of Iran by the detractors of deal. How else the clamour for further tightening of screws over the already agreed aspects of Iranian nuclear programme could be rationally justified? More so when the deal has not yet arrived at an actual take off stage. When the US could show an exemplary courage against all the heavy odds of a sustained vitriolic opposition to the deal by its allies, both western as well as from the Middle East, it behooves on it to carry the process to logical end also by helping guide Iran to turn its nuclear programme compliant to global peace aspirations, and its own legitimate development needs, without raising doubts about the Iranian intentions and goals.

I come out of academia and over the past 30 years I could not help but notice that gender equality as happened there has gone with quite unequal hiring when race and class are factored in. It seems that when gender is discussed, it is done so on the supposition of a biological condition--men/women. But socially considered, the children of attorneys, male or female, do much better because the incomes of their parents can support expensive private schools; most Latina women, married or not, working or not, simply can't afford to yank their children out of, e.g., the ruinous L.A. public school system. Gender is not primary other than in the way we continue to describe it; what is primary is all sorts of obedience demanded by employers as the cost of achieving a high income.

I think you are personally bitter. If women are marginalized, made fun of, and passed over in science why have so many women reached the top (Lisa Randall in physics for one example). I was in physics and never saw any women treated badly.
Dave: just because you didn't see something doesn't mean it's not there.  Discrimination isn't necessarily overt; I see it all the time and am tired of it.

Good job of telling it like it is. I am saving this very direct little essay for my files. I happen to find myself in an abusive social situation and your comment brings me some validation and relief. I feel encouraged to take action instead of just ignoring the man as I've been advised, because he "has his ways". Huh?

Thanks for the lift.

Here's one way to reduce the inequality;  stop assuming that single childless adults need less money to live on than those who are married or have children, or both.  Stop promoting according to stereotypes and promote based on competence.  As a woman in the sciences I have been ignored, made fun of, underpaid, and condescended to far more than my male colleagues.  When I have tried to bring problems to the attention of my male supervisors they have, for the most part acted like it was a female problem.  When another male brought the same problem to their attention they were more than happy to solve it.  Stop calling women aggressive when they are being assertive.  Stop muttering about women being on the rag when they are telling you to do your job or if they, like men, lose their tempers on occasion.  Women are people and as such should be treated with the same respect men expect.  Too many men do not understand how it feels to be ignored, condescended to, have ideas stolen, or told that one is less worthy because of one's gender because they are the gender in power.  Science, especially in IT, is still a men's club.  Women are marginalized, made fun of, passed over for promotions and when it happens once too often, they leave.  It's not that women aren't willing to work hard.  We get tired of fighting the stereotype over and over again because it's a waste of time.  Men would do better to start working with women rather than against them.

Actually, you are proving the point of the article.  What do I mean? Well, spending on education, narrowly defined, is similar to spending on health care, narrowly  defined. Unless students are living in situations where their basic needs are reliably met, it is a truism that on average they will have trouble learning.

As a majority we're a nation who believes in helping each other.

http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2012/12/18/a-bipartisan-nation-of-benefic...

The minority who believes they should be able to filibuster everything Democrats want to do is the minority that believes that government is best shrunk to a suitable size for drowning in a bathtub.

They're the same minority that is sequestering to death important programs, the same minority that refuses to allow the Bush tax cuts to expire as they originally said they would, the same minority that Mitt Romney suggested might find it better to trade Veterans benefits for a voucher program, the same minority that threatened the nations international credibility and limited funding the federal government through January 15 and imposed a debt ceiling deadline of February 7...

The argument over Affordable Care is really no more than a symptom of what amounts to as much as an HIV infection of goverment, a disease in the body politic that is tenaciously about bringing federal government down, regardless of the requirement in their resources to accomplish that end.

They've been at it since FDR and gained great ground since 1980, destroying unions, limiting income, sequestering wealth, maligning social programs, and cutting taxes to the point that our very infrastructure is threatened.

Affordable Care is just one more problem for them to tackle, and they relish the possibility of achieving the goal of destroying it.
.
Why?

Sorry, but you haven't run the statistical models to justify your dire predictions. You are simply blowing hot air. You've heard lots about the "death spiral" because you've been watching and listening to right-wing media, which have rotted your brain. Do yourself a favor: detoxify your system by turning  off Fox and Limbaugh.

The subsidized poor and near poor are not subsidized by healthy young people, but by everyone who pays federal taxes. The more tax you pay, the more you contribute to the expansion of Medicaid to cover all people with incomes below 133% of the Poverty Level. The money to pay to subsidize premiums for people making more will come from federal taxes and from tax penalties on people who should but don't sign up for insurance. It is true that surpluses from premiums paid by the young help pay for care of the elderly. Also, surpluses from premiums paid by the healthy pay for the increased care required by people with preexisting conditions. JJHLH doesn’t mention it, but it is also true that these surpluses cover insurance company profits and the salaries and perks of their top executives.

However, these same facts prevail in the traditional employer provided insurance market. The employee pays a share of the premium which is not based on his or her age, although the premium the insurance company charges the company may be based in part on the average age of all the employees in the company. Again surpluses generated by younger and healthier patients are covering the higher health care costs of older patients and those with preexisting conditions. Also, they are doing more to maintain insurance company profits. When JJHLH says that young people won't let themselves be robbed, I wonder how many have chosen individual market insurance over employer sponsored insurance.

You're attacking the very concept of insurance: where people who are less likely to receive benefits (for now) pay into a system along with people who do receive them.  And guess what--young people do need medical care occasionally.  Have you visited an orthopedic hospital lately?  I did, and saw more people in their 20s and 30s than in any other age group.  Torn ACLs, broken ankles, and other sports-related injuries tend not to happen so much to the sick and elderly.  Those young people with insurance didn't feel as though they'd been robbed.

Sorry, Mr. Krugman, but I strongly disagree with your conclusions.

Obamacare is not going to work because it is based on a fundamental flaw. The Obamacare scheme transfers money from young healthy people to support older patients, those with preexisting conditions, and the subsidized poor. Young people are not going to let themselves be robbed. The Obama Administration itself estimates that 38% of enrollees need to be below age 35 for the math to work. The fact that only 22% of California's enrollees are that age, as you note, is a very ominous sign. That almost certainly means adverse risk selection is occurring which will lead to increase premiums next year, causing even fewer young and healthy people to participate. That is the "death spiral" we have heard so much about, and is why Obamacare will ultimately fail. It will collapse on itself financially as it already has politically. No amount of cheerleading is going to change that.

Vertical Farms solve the fossil fuel issues as well as pesticide runoffs. Www.TerraSphereSystems.com has an organic solution which is cost effective and its indoor farms use the latest LED lighting technology in warehouses.
Vertical Farming has enormous potential and brings food everywhere without traveling long distances.

Interesting article whose subject warrants intensive study.  Urban farming alternatives, including technology-intensive indoor vertical farms, also warrant review as a means of feeding growing populations.

When you write that "[e]very time the federal governmant has taken from producers to hand cash or benefits to its recipient class it has held on to most of the cash... " you are factually wrong.

But you knew this.

Social Security and Medicare are both among the most efficient programs anywhere. Back in the Depression, the WPA was found by independent auditors to be both honest and highly efficient. There's also veteran's benefits as a good example.

It's the private insurance companies and Wall Street that extract obscene profits from the middle class that hold on to most of the money. That's why the ACA forces private insurers to pay out in benefits most of what they take in.

The real redistribution in the U.S. is from the working poor and middle classes to the rich.

At least here in Florida, from healthcare.gov., I was able to preview the policies for which I qualified.  I have a policy from my employer--which remained exactly the same for next year, as it happens--but I wanted to see what was available if I wanted to independently buy my own policy.  While I didn't file an application that would have told me what price reductions I might have received based on income, I easily found the cost of the basic plans, and they were, I thought, reasonable.
When something can be explained by government incompetence or malice, usually incompetence is the explanation.

We have to wonder whether the Obama crew really wanted the national website to work. Citizens had to almost complete the process before finding out any prices at all, in stark comparison to - what, a million? successful business websites serving those same people.

Especially before the Virginia governor election, people want to know if the federal site was intentionally slowed down so not too many people would find that their costs would be thousands of dollars per year more - especially those important young adults who haven't ever bought a big comprehensive policy before.

Every time the federal government has taken from producers to hand cash or benefits to its recipient class it has held onto most of the cash, burning it in offices and fiefdoms in D.C. and at the state level of bureaucrats answering to D.C. How ironic that its boosters here don't ever get around to mentioning that reality.

If this waste of money repeats itself in the Obamacare redistribution scheme, a world of people are going to be infuriated, even if dozens of millions of ID theft crimes weren't going to be the undiscussed stepchildren of Mr. Obama's little transformation project.

Thank you so much for this!  You took the words out of my mouth.  I totally support women's rights, equal pay, but it drives me crazy when almost any woman who supports this goes on to say that they would never date a man who makes less than them, then actively persues only men who act macho and are in macho fields of work.
I think it's a lot simpler than that -- men are just less interested than women in taking care of little kids, and more interested in levers, gears, and the shedding of human blood.

Steve,

So you are saying that women are engaging in the same stereotypes that victimize them, and that these perspectives also victimize males?

Well said. Women have always bought into their own subjection; just look at the number of anti-feminist women in the last two centuries. And so these women will also participate in the stereotyping of men, and will devalue those who do not adhere to the "manly man" image.

That prejudice, held by both women and men, is what we are fighting against, in case you didn't notice.

I'm surprised that, as a sociologist, Cohen appears to be somewhat presumptive. in how he views the evidence. In a sense his analysis is the analog of supply side economics: if only there wasn't a pay differential, men would be more likely to go into "women's" professions, especially if they could get over thinking of them as feminine.

What Cohen misses is a very important demand aspect of the situation: how women view men. In education, the vast majority of primary school teachers are still women. The reason for this, I would argue, is not a pay differential, especially in today's economy, where teachers' jobs are relatively secure and well compensated (though not nearly as much so as they should be.) Nor do men, by and large, stay away from the field because they think it is "sissy." Rather, it is because they viscerally understand that to acquire a mate (wife, partner, girlfriend, whatever), they have to be desirable. To put it simply, I have never heard of a girl who fantasized growing up and marrying a kindergarten teacher. Yes, most women explicitly support the idea of men teaching in the early grades. However, that is an abstraction, and unless and until women demonstrate that they will take those guys home with them and stay with them, men will stay out of those positions.

Another deterrent to men's involvement as grade school teachers is the public perception of men, not women, as potential pedophiles, thus producing a more suspicious work environment for men.
Don't forget Loretta Sanchez, who unseated "B-1 Bob" Dornan. Even Orange County is starting to go blue.

so how about the 900,000 people in Calif that have had their insurance cancelled because of ACA?  As of today, more Californias have had their insurance cancelled than have signed up.  So because of ACA there are more people currently uninsured in California since Oct 1.

Thank you for saying this. I have wondered why the MSM (including NPR) continues to hammer at ACA and never, never seems to challenge the rights "talking points" which have not been accurate on any topic what so ever.

The rollout of Obamacare has only been a "Disaster" in the extent to which the Mainstream media has adopted the that right wing talking points. But then, according to Republicans, California is not (Other than Orange County) representative of the "real" America.

Which is about as honest as their continued insistence that financial deregulation and tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans have had (and will have) only beneficial effects on our economy.

The real disaster here has been the extent to which the media has merely parroted right wing talking points, instead of doing it's job of pointing out that many of the problems are due to the roadblocks to implementation built by the Republicans.

Tha's scary.
Ah yes, how did people ever survive the winter before the New Deal and the government?
Extraordinarily good advice!
@truth2power: the people we are talking about died, may they rest in peace.

I believe that Republican governors are worried that they will lose their jobs should the health care law be successful. Here in Maine, Governor LePage has steadfastly refused the Medicaid expansion, leaving thousands of Mainers without any recourse to help. With the cold weather now upon us, many of these people will suffer needlessly. Some will likely die.

We have a great solution to the problem, and his name is Mike Michaud. As Rima Rigas said, voting the recalcitrant politicians out of office is a start.

This is a great post with plenty of good points. The last paragraph, however, might be off a bit. The idea of "starve the beast" became a behind the scenes credo of Republicans in part because they didn't get a full plate (or better yet, an empty plate) of what they wanted in the Reagan years. Reagan was radical on some matters, but he was, at heart, something of an ordinary American. He didn't want to tear down and destroy the nation, its govt., or the fundamental accomplishments of the previous 100 yrs. He was also willing to compromise.

Starve the beast was another way of saying, if taken to its logical conclusion, that it would be great to drive the federal enterprise into bankruptcy. That way, the Republican belief that govt. can't do anything right would be demonstrated to the world and everything, except defense spending, would have to be cut to the bone. The actual program, too much spending, two wars plus tax cuts, was put into place under G.W.Bush.

The ACA marks the end game for the Republican anti-government argument. They will, of course, continue to bellow out the same tune, but many fewer will be listening. The last great piece of what started with FDR during the Great Depression will be in place. The only way forward with the same ideology would be to engineer an actual, unstoppable bankruptcy of our nation, something even their business and wealthy clients, in the main, would oppose.

In bed on a Kindle.
